subject: Re: Is there an accent problem?
msgSnippet: Michael and others, Michael asks, If some mental acrobatics is required with any standardized phonemic system, is spelling reform worth campaigning for? A
messageBody:
Michael and others,

Michael asks, If some mental acrobatics is required with any
standardized phonemic system, is spelling reform worth campaigning
for?

A phonemic system based on NBC-English with certain allowances for
BBC-English would require much fewer mental gymnastics than the
present system. The phonemic spelling would be a reliable guide to
NBC-English, a dialect that most people are exposed to, and
relatively easy to spell as long as one recalled the NBC
pronunciation.

In my travels I have met a number of people who can speak passable
English but when they tried to write it they were unintelligible.
A phonemic system would make the transition from speaking to
spelling much easier to navigate.

I am not that concerned about the change in regional dialects. I
think most their changes would probably be in the direction of
broadcast English.

"Hir iz qn exammpl av sumthing ritten in foanemic NBC inglish. It iz
not thqt haard tu ried or rait. It is diffrent and sum wvd sey
odd/aad lvking."

trailing dbl consonants mark short stressed vowels
o = something between aa and aw, normally Q [british short o]
q = [italic a] a. ae as in ax
v = U as in hook
O = oa oU @U as in oat.
u = ^ as in up. where available use circumflex u.
uu= u: as in ooze and pool.





--- In Read_Alphabet@y..., Michael Fitzgerald <mchlf@y...> wrote:
> Hallo Steve and folks...
>
> > If people spell as they speak and they use a
> > regional dialect, their
> > transcriptions are not going to match those with
> > other accents.
>
> True: and that, (for me), is part of the attraction
> of learning a phonetic script.
>
> > One almost needs a pronunciation dictionary for
> > every major dialect
> > of English. www.fonetik.com has started moving in
> > this direction.
>
> And then of course, you need to _keep_ moving, because
> accent change is a much more fluid process than
> spelling change. A Birmingham or a Dublin accent is
> quite different from a their equivalents 50 years ago.
> I guess the change is going to be slower for MAJOR
> dialects, but it's bound to happen.
>
> >A standardized phonemic
> > system would also
> > standardize pronunciation or at least require that
> > some words be
> > repronounced in order to be spelled correctly.
>
> So the mental acrobatics required for reading from a
> standardised phonemic system can be the same as those
> required to read from a non-standardised phonemic
> system i.e. "phonetically that word says X, whereas I
> would pronounce it Y, but I recognise it as meaning Z
> anyway."
>
> With all that in mind, is a BIG widely used spelling
> reform system any use to anyone? is it worth
> campaigning for? what's wrong with just using as a
> personal note taking system or as a kind of 'light'
> phonetic transcription system?
>
> just asking - regards,
> Michael
